712377f-a.text:
37th Street, south side, west from No. 318 between First and Second Avenues, showing St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church and parish
house at 30B East 37th Street.
July 13, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

712375f-a.text:
(1)
37th Street, south side, west from First Avenue, also showing
643-641 First Avenue.
April 8, 1931.

(2)
A view solely of East 37th Street. Shown east of Second Ave. is St.  Gabriel's R.C. Church. Note the Empire State Building in the background.
October 12, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

707589f-a.text:
First Avenue, at East 37th Street, showing the Queens Midtown Tunnel under construction at the S. W. corner. The buildings on the right are on the east side of the Avenue, extending from 37th to 39th Street's. The stacks shown are atop the Consolidated Edison Co. generating plant at the East River. The photographer is viewing northeastward from a vantage point on 36th Street, between First and Second Avenue's.
June 28, 1939
October 11, 1939
P. L. Sperr

707589f-b.text:
First Avenue, at East 37th Street, showing the Queens Midtown Tunnel under construction at the S. W. corner. 707592f-a.text:
First Avenue, west side, from E. 37th to 38th Streets, showing a fenced in clearance thru which is running the diagonal cut for the Queens Midtown tunnel. At the right is the Eleto Co. warehouse, housing the "United Parcel' service.
January, 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

707594f-a.text:
First Avenue, east side, gorth from E. 37th to 39th Streets. The former Kips Bay Brewery occupies the 37th-38th Street frontage, while above same are power houses of the Censolidated
Edison Co.
January 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
5~5 Mgrk City Tunoel Authority

712371f-a.text:
E. 37th Street, west of First avenue. Across the foreground and enclosed by fences is the diagonal cut that will carry the approach to the Wueens Midtown Tunnel.
January 7, 1939
Somach Fhbto Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

712390f-a.text:
300 to 310 E. 37th Street, at, adjourning and east of the S. E. corner of Second Avenue (right), as viewed south westward from: a point midway between First and Second Avenues. Proriently shown is St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church established here August 15, 1859 by the Rev. William H. Clowry. The late Cardinal Farley, then a Monsignor, was pastor from 188d to 1902. His assistant ouring part of that time was the subseouent Cardinal, Patrick J. Hayes. For an account of the last Mass held here, see the New York Times of January l6, 1939.
Demolition will occur in June 1939.
January 25, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

712372f-a.text:
E. 37th Street, west from First Avenue, showing in the foreground the Queens Midtown Tunnel clearance. The balance of the buildings on the left were subsequently demolished. This included St. Gabriel's Church appearing in the right center. Note the hazy outline of the Empire State Building in the background.
January 7, 1939
Somach Photo Service
New York City Tunnel Authority

712374f-b.text:
East 37th Street, west from First Avenue, showing progress on the demolition for the Midtown-Queens Tunnel. In a skeletal condition stands St. Gabriel's Chnrch and School. Tenements on the north side of this thoroughfare will remain. Note the Second Avenue Elevated and the towering Empire State Building.
May 27, 1939
Views: 1-2-3
P. L Sperr

712373f-a.text:
East 37th Street, at First Avenue, showing constructional details of the Manhattan Approach to the ,ueensMTidtown Tunnel under the East River. The buildings on the left are on the north side of 37th Street; those on the right are on the east side of First Avenue. The photographers vantage point is 36th Street, east of Second Avenue. The direction is northeast.
October 11, 1939
April 11, 1940
P. L. Sperr

The direction is northeast.

707590f-b.text:
First Avenue, at East 37th Street, showing the entrance to the Midtown-Queens Tunnel at the S. E. corner. The industrial plants shown are on the east side of the Avenue. East 37th Street proper is on the left. The Tunnel curves northward under the Avenue to pass under the East River at about 40th Street.
September 21, 1940
No's. 1-2
P. L. Sperr
